service centers https://teslamotorsclub.com/tmc/threads/has-the-quality-of-tesla-service-gone-into-the-toilet.76908/page-3 -->
===Sales model===
Tesla operates more than 200 stores and galleries around the world, 120 of which are outside the USA. It owns the stores and sells directly to customers via the internet and in non-US stores.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/teslamotors/comments/3uulo3/does_anyone_know_how_many_stores_tesla_has_over/ |title=Does anyone know how many stores Tesla has over the years? • /r/teslamotors|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[https://gpwrite.wordpress.com/2016/03/31/number-of-tesla-stores/ Number of Tesla Stores]<!--92 US in March 2016--></ref><ref>[https://www.tesla.com/findus/list List]<!--amount not shown--></ref>{{Better source|reason=All three sources are either primary sources or self published|date=May 2016}}<!--102 US in November 2015 http://blog.caranddriver.com/teslas-direct-sales-gambit-would-be-nothing-without-its-cars/ --><!-- sales details https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Vobg29R1t3FphlWjb8dwG4nkAWqyc_qMwkCjUT8SUno/pubhtml?gid=1805961368&single=true&chrome=false -->
Tesla has a low<!--not zero--> budget for [[Marketing communications|marketing]], and uses a [[Referral marketing|referral program]] and [[word of mouth]] to attract buyers.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.inc.com/walter-chen/how-teslas-referral-program-generates-more-than-40x-roi.html |title=How Tesla's Referral Program Generates More Than 40x ROI|website=Inc.com|accessdate=16 October 2016}}<!--40x ROI seems to be a special case, not general. Beware of other links that include referral codes, as they serve as advertising for that owner--></ref>
==US dealerships and automotive dealership disputes== <!--alternative; History of Tesla automotive dealership disputes in the USA --> [[File:Tesla store, Austin, Texas 01.jpg|thumb|Tesla gallery in [[Austin, Texas]].]] {{ external media |align=right | image1 =[http://www.autonews.com/article/20140301/RETAIL/140229855/teslas-state-by-state-battle-with-dealers Map of direct automaker sales], regarding Tesla conditions. [https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://www.autonews.com/article/20140301/RETAIL/140229855/teslas-state-by-state-battle-with-dealers Archive] }}<!-- store/gallery at http://www.tesla.com/findus#/bounds/49.38,-66.94,25.82,-124.38999999999999,d?search=store,&name=USA --> There are stores and galleries<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thecarconnection.com/news/1079679_tesla-accused-of-operating-illegal-showrooms-in-4-states |title=Tesla Accused of Operating Illegal Showrooms in 4 States |website=The Car Connection |accessdate=2015-04-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.triplepundit.com/2013/01/blow-car-dealers-court-affirms-teslas-operate-company-owned-stores/ |title=Court Affirms Tesla's Right to Operate Company-Owned Stores |author=Harry Stevens |date=2013-01-15 |accessdate=2015-04-12 |website=Triple Pundit: People, Planet, Profit}}</ref>—usually located in shopping malls—in 26 US states and Washington DC<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tesla.com/findus/list/stores/United+States|title=US Tesla Stores and Galleries {{!}} Tesla|website=www.tesla.com|access-date=2018-02-10}}</ref>. Customers cannot buy vehicles from stores,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/markrogowsky/2013/12/04/ohio-tables-anti-tesla-dealer-protection-law-for-now/ |work=Forbes |first=Mark |last=Rogowsky |title=Ohio To Tesla: We're Ignoring Our Whiny Car Dealers For Now, Come Sell Here |date=2013-12-04 |accessdate=2014-05-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2013/11/20/tesla-battles-auto-dealers-direct-sales-consumers/3f1xBFN21xH8QqQc3jijTP/story.html |title=Tesla battles auto dealers on direct sales to consumers - Business - The Boston Globe |website=Boston Globe |first=Callum |last=Borchers |date=2013-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1084622_tesla-loses-legal-battles-to-texas-north-carolina-dealers |title=Tesla Loses Legal Battles To Texas, North Carolina Dealers |author=John Voelcker |website=Green Car Reports |accessdate=2015-04-12}}</ref> only from the Tesla website.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tesla.com/models/design |title=Model S Design Studio |publisher=Tesla Motors |accessdate=2015-04-12}}</ref> The stores serve as showrooms that allow people to learn about the company and its vehicles.<ref name=7reasons/> Some galleries are located in states with restrictive dealership protection laws which prevent discussing price, financing, and test drives, as well as other restrictions. Tesla has set up [[Intermodal container|mobile-shipping-container]] "stores"<ref name=fast2016-08-08/> and 6 [[Airstream]] [[travel trailer]]s each pulled by a Model X, reaching areas not served by [[Brick and mortar|brick-and-mortar shops]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/9/8/12846314/tesla-mobile-dealer-explores-airstream |title=Tesla is going on a road trip to sell cars|date=8 September 2016|publisher=Vox Media|website=The Verge|accessdate=9 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tesla.com/teslaexplores |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160909150633/https://www.tesla.com/teslaexplores |title=Tesla Explores|archivedate=9 September 2016|publisher=Tesla Motors|accessdate=9 September 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Tesla's strategy of direct customer sales and owning stores and service centers is different from the standard dealership model in the US vehicle marketplace.<ref name=TCC>{{cite web |url=http://www.thecarconnection.com/news/1092795_terrified-of-tesla-nada-launches-campaign-to-tout-benefits-of-franchise-dealerships |title=Terrified of Tesla, NADA Launches Campaign To Tout Benefits of Franchise Dealerships |author=Richard Read |website=The Car Connection |accessdate=2015-07-16}}</ref> Tesla is the only manufacturer that sells cars directly to customers; all other automakers use independently owned dealerships<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/business/2013/12/03/auto-dealers-seek-to-stop-teslas-way-of-selling.html |title=Auto dealers in Ohio seek to stop Tesla's way of direct selling |author=Dan Gearino |website=The Columbus Dispatch |accessdate=2015-04-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2013/07/02/autos/tesla-petition/ |publisher=CNN |first=James |last=O'Toole |title=Tesla direct-sales petition hits 100,000 signatures |date=2013-07-02 |accessdate=2015-04-12}}</ref> (partly due to earlier conflict),<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/10/13/business/fight-is-promised-over-gm-plan-to-buy-dealerships.html |work=The New York Times |first=Keith |last=Bradsher |title=Fight Is Promised Over G.M. Plan to Buy Dealerships |date=October 13, 1999}}</ref><ref name=wp2014-03>{{cite news |first=Charles |last=Lane |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/charles-lane-tesla-takes-on-car-dealerships-in-a-fight-to-the-death/2014/03/12/2956a9f2-a9ff-11e3-8599-ce7295b6851c_story.html |work=[[The Washington Post]] |title=Tesla takes on car dealerships in a fight to the death |date=2014-03-12 |accessdate=2015-05-20}}</ref><ref>Crane, Daniel A. "[http://repository.law.umich.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2720&context=articles Tesla, Dealer Franchise Laws, and the Politics of Crony Capitalism]" page 577-579. [[Iowa Law Review|Iowa L. Rev]]. 101, no. 2 (2016): 573-607 . Size: 35 pages in 1 MegaByte</ref> although some automakers provide online configuration and financing.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303492504579111752452221502 |title=GM Opens the Door to Online New-Car Sales - WSJ |author=Christina Rogers |date=2013-10-07 |work=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=2015-07-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thecarconnection.com/news/1087492_gm-follows-teslas-lead-plans-to-sell-directly-to-online-shoppers |title=GM Follows Tesla's Lead, Plans To Sell Directly To Online Shoppers |author=Richard Read |website=The Car Connection |accessdate=2015-07-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thecarconnection.com/news/1097703_scion-almost-lets-you-buy-a-car-at-home-take-delivery-at-dealership |title=Scion Lets You (Almost) Buy A Car at Home, Take Delivery at Dealership |author=Bengt Halvorson |website=The Car Connection |accessdate=2015-07-16}}</ref> 48 states have laws that limit or ban manufacturers from selling vehicles directly to consumers,<ref>{{cite news |last=Voelcker |first=John |title=Auto Dealers' Fight Against Tesla Stores: Elon Musk Weighs In |url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1080001_auto-dealers-fight-against-tesla-stores-elon-musk-weighs-in |accessdate=2014-02-10 |newspaper=Green Car Reports |date=2012-10-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://jalopnik.com/how-texas-absurd-anti-tesla-laws-turn-car-buying-into-1451492195 |title=How Texas's Absurd Anti-Tesla Laws Turn Car Buying into A Joke |author=David Noland |website=Jalopnik |accessdate=2015-04-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-06-20/news/ct-oped-0620-chapman-20130620_1_tesla-motors-car-dealers-car-costs |work=Chicago Tribune |first=Steve |last=Chapman |title=Car buyers get hijacked |date=2013-06-20 |accessdate=2015-04-12}}</ref> and although Tesla has no independent dealerships, dealership associations in multiple states have filed numerous lawsuits against Tesla, to prevent the company from selling cars. North Carolina and New Hampshire sided with Tesla, while Virginia and Texas sided with dealers.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://gas2.org/2013/07/01/tesla-wins-big-in-north-carolina-and-new-hampshire |title=Tesla Wins Big in North Carolina And New Hampshire |first=Christopher |last=DeMorro |work=Gas 2 |date=2013-07-01 |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref> Lack of outlets, and much lower electric vehicle maintenance requirements, reduce the need for service centers. Tesla currently has service centers in 25 states.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tesla.com/findus/list/services/United+States|title=US Tesla Service Centers {{!}} Tesla|website=www.tesla.com|access-date=2018-02-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://247wallst.com/autos/2016/08/15/need-a-tesla-service-center-dont-live-in-most-states/ |title=Need a Tesla Service Center? Don't Look in Most States |date= 2016-08-15 |website=247wallst.com |accessdate= 2016-08-15}}</ref> Media cited direct sales or lack thereof as reasons when selecting the site for [[Gigafactory 1]].<ref name=boyd>[http://www.theboydcompany.com/docs/Intelligent%20Utility.pdf How did Texas lose its bid for Tesla's 'gigafactory'?] [https://web.archive.org/web/20160801154930/http://www.theboydcompany.com/docs/Intelligent%20Utility.pdf Archive] 2014-09-04</ref><ref name=jalop2014>{{cite web|url= http://jalopnik.com/why-this-state-is-the-most-likely-to-get-teslas-gigafa-1554902271 |title=Why This State Is The Most Likely To Get Tesla's Gigafactory|website=Jalopnik |date=2014-01-04 |accessdate= 2016-11-04 |quote=Tesla's ongoing war with car dealers over their direct-to-customer car sales model, which is limited or banned outright by law in several states.}}</ref>
Countries other than USA do not have such laws protecting car dealerships.<ref name=fast2016-08-08/> The [[Federal Trade Commission]] recommends allowing direct manufacturer sales,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/blogs/competition-matters/2015/05/direct-consumer-auto-sales-its-not-just-about-tesla |title=Direct-to-consumer auto sales: It's not just about Tesla |accessdate=2015-07-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thecarconnection.com/news/1098273_can-the-ftc-persuade-michigan-other-states-to-open-their-doors-to-tesla |title=Can The FTC Persuade Michigan & Other States To Open Their Doors To Tesla? |author=Richard Read |website=The Car Connection |accessdate=2015-07-16}}</ref> which analysts believe would save buyers 8% per purchase on average.<ref name=wp2014-03/><ref>"[http://www.justice.gov/atr/public/eag/246374.htm Economic Effects of State Bans on Direct Manufacturer Sales to Car Buyers]" ''Economic Analysis Group Competition Advocacy'', May 2009.</ref> In May 2014, a report prepared by [[Maryann Keller]] and Kenneth Elias for the [[National Automobile Dealers Association]] states that franchises (such as offered by its members) offer better value for customers than direct sales.<ref name=TCC /><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nada.org/WorkArea/DownloadAsset.aspx?id=21474838844 |title=Consumer Benefits of the Dealer Franchise System |first1=Maryann |last1=Keller |first2=Kenneth |last2=Elias |publisher=[[National Automobile Dealers Association]] |date=2014-05-27 |accessdate=2016-01-31}}<!-- of course a DEALER association says DEALERS offer a better value. WP:Balance --></ref><ref>http://www.phoenix-center.org/pcpp/PCPP48Final.pdf</ref>
==States with total direct sales bans==
===Michigan (also bans service centers)=== On October 1, 2014, Michigan [[Michigan House of Representatives|House]] Bill 5606, drafted "to keep automakers from forcing dealers to charge different documentation fees to different customers,"<ref>{{Cite news |title=Tesla's sales limits in Michigan tightened by one word of law |url=http://www.autonews.com/article/20141020/RETAIL/141029995/teslas-sales-limits-in-michigan-tightened-by-one-word-of-law |date=2014-10-21 |first=Chris |last=Gautz |publisher=[[Crain Communications, Inc.]] |accessdate=2014-10-21}}</ref> was amended with a section stating that a manufacturer shall not "sell any new motor vehicle directly to a retail customer other than through its franchised dealers." The word "its" was removed, which assumed the manufacturer already had dealerships. Both houses passed the revised bill the next day, with only one nay vote from [[Tom McMillin]] in either house of the [[Michigan Legislature]]. Tesla argued that the original law would have allowed them to sell, because they did not yet have franchised dealers.<ref>{{Cite news |title=New Jersey bans direct auto sales |url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/business/autos/2014/10/16/tesla-faces-direct-sales-ban-michigan/17359253/ |date=2014-10-16 |first1=Michael |last1=Martinez |first2=Michael |last2=Wayland |publisher=[[The Detroit News]] |agency=Business Insider.com |accessdate=2014-10-21}}</ref> On October 21, [[General Motors]] released a statement saying that governor [[Rick Snyder]] should sign the bill into law because "we believe that House Bill 5606 will help ensure that all automotive manufacturers follow the same rules to operate in the State of Michigan." The same day, Snyder signed the bill. Tesla responded to the GM statement by saying "GM distorts the purpose of the franchise laws which are in place not to cement a monopoly for franchised dealers, but rather to prevent companies with existing franchises from unfairly competing against them."<ref>{{Cite news |title=Michigan Governor Signs Anti-Tesla Bill: Law Bars Auto Makers From Directly Selling to Consumers |url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/gm-urges-michigan-gov-to-sign-anti-tesla-bill-1413912419 |date=2014-10-21 |first1=Joseph B. |last1=White |first2=Jeff |last2=Bennett |work=The Wall Street Journal |publisher=[[Dow Jones & Company, Inc.]] |accessdate=2014-10-21}}</ref> The law in Michigan even bans manufacturers from operating service centers<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/business/autos/2015/05/11/ftc-michigan-tesla/27122673/ |title=FTC urges Michigan to drop Tesla sales ban |first=David |last=Shepardson |work=Detroit News |date=2015-05-12 |accessdate=2015-08-21}}</ref> and from giving [[test drive]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://electrek.co/2016/07/28/tesla-owners-test-drives-michigan-circumventing-tesla-sales-ban/|title=Tesla owners give test drives in Michigan circumventing the Tesla sales ban|first=Fred|last=Lambert|date=28 July 2016|publisher=}}</ref> According to Tesla, the law was changed to also prohibit galleries.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.freep.com/story/money/cars/general-motors/2014/10/17/michigan-verge-banning-tesla-stores/17386251/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160704210020/http://www.freep.com/story/money/cars/general-motors/2014/10/17/michigan-verge-banning-tesla-stores/17386251/ |title=Gov. Snyder signs bill banning direct Tesla sales|date=17 October 2014|archivedate=4 July 2016|website=[[Detroit Free Press]]|accessdate=17 September 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref> Michigan denied Tesla's request for a gallery in September 2016,<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.freep.com/story/money/cars/2016/09/15/s-final-michigan-wont-let-tesla-open-dealership/90427536/ |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160917023341/http://www.freep.com/story/money/cars/2016/09/15/s-final-michigan-wont-let-tesla-open-dealership/90427536/ |title=It's final: Michigan won't let Tesla open a dealership in Grand Rapids|date=15 September 2016|archivedate=17 September 2016|website=[[Detroit Free Press]]|accessdate=17 September 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref> and Tesla filed a federal lawsuit against the State.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-29/tesla-takes-fight-on-sales-ban-to-home-turf-of-detroit-three |title=Tesla Takes Fight on Sales Ban to Home Turf of Detroit Three|website=Bloomberg.com |date= 2016-09-29 |accessdate= 2016-12-02}}</ref> Tesla opened a gallery showroom in the [[Nordstrom]] shop in the [[Somerset Collection|Somerset]] shopping mall in [[Troy, Michigan]] in December 2016, with a "Not For Sale" sign on the displayed car.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://electrek.co/2016/12/02/tesla-michigans-direct-sales-law-showroom/ |title=Tesla pushes boundaries of Michigan's direct sales law and opens showroom in the state|date= 2016-12-02 |website=Electrek|accessdate= 2016-12-02}}</ref>
===New Mexico (also bans service centers)=== 2006 New Mexico Statutes, Section 57-16-5-V prohibits manufacturers like Tesla to be licensed as a dealer, directly or indirectly performing warranty or other services.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://law.justia.com/codes/new-mexico/2006/nmrc/jd_57-16-5-13229.html|title=2006 New Mexico Statutes - Section 57-16-5 — Unlawful acts; manufacturers; distributors; representatives.|work=Justia Law|access-date=2018-01-12|language=en}}</ref> Despite Tesla owners' pleas to change the law, they still currently depend on out-of-state centers such as Arizona and Colorado for Tesla sales and services.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.santafenewmexican.com/news/business/tesla-owners-urge-legislators-to-overhaul-dealership-law/article_5278f6a2-bf99-5659-92b3-43b04ee4fd8a.html|title=Tesla owners urge legislators to overhaul dealership law|last=Mexican|first=Bruce KrasnowThe New|work=The Santa Fe New Mexican|access-date=2018-01-12|language=en}}</ref>
===Alabama (also bans service centers)=== [[Alabama]] regards manufacturer-owned new motor vehicle stores and service centers as "unfair and deceptive trade practices".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://codes.lp.findlaw.com/alcode/8/20/8-20-4#sthash.voQJG5Jn.dpuf|title=Alabama Code - Section 8-20-4: Unfair and Deceptive Trade Practices|website=[[FindLaw]] |accessdate=2016-08-21 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150909135908/http://codes.lp.findlaw.com/alcode/8/20/8-20-4 |archivedate=2015-09-09 |deadurl=no |quote=s. To own an interest in a new motor vehicle dealership, to operate or control a dealership, to make direct sales or leases of new motor vehicles to the public in Alabama, or to own, operate, or control a facility for performance of motor vehicle warranty or repair service work}}</ref> In August 2016 State Senator Tom Whatley introduced Senate Bill 22, assigned to the Senate Tourism and Marketing Committee, which would allow a manufacturer of alternative fuel vehicles to sell and lease its vehicles directly to the public.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://electrek.co/2016/08/19/tesla-alabama-sell-vehicles-directly-senate-bill/ |title= Tesla tries to sell its vehicles directly in Alabama, senator introduces new bill |website= electrek.co |first= Fred |last= Lambert |date= 2016-08-19 |accessdate= 2016-08-21}}</ref> The bill never made it out of committee.
===South Carolina (also bans service centers)=== [[South Carolina]] bans manufacturer ownership of new car dealerships and manufacturer service/repair of cars they do not own.
===Louisiana (also bans service centers)=== [[Louisiana]] enacted a law in June 2017 that bans direct to consumer sales of vehicles. <ref>{{cite web|last1=Meachum|first1=Alex|title=Tesla speaks out against La bill|url=http://www.arklatexhomepage.com/news/local-news/tesla-speaks-out-against-la-bill/732494733|website=arklatex|publisher=arklatex|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Dolzer|first1=Mike|title=Tesla hit with new Louisiana law that prohibits direct sales in state|url=https://www.teslarati.com/louisiana-law-prohibit-tesla-direct-sales/|website=teslarati|publisher=teslarati|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref><ref>[http://www.mercurynews.com/2017/06/06/tesla-says-new-law-will-prohibit-direct-sales-in-louisiana/ Tesla says new law will prohibit direct sales in Louisiana], June 6, 2017, The Associated Press</ref>
===Texas=== Texas law states "Except as provided by this section, a manufacturer or distributor may not directly or indirectly:(1) own an interest in a franchised or nonfranchised dealer or dealership;(2) operate or control a franchised or nonfranchised dealer or dealership; or(3) act in the capacity of a franchised or nonfranchised dealer. (Tex. Occ. Code Ann. § 2301.476) and "A motor vehicle shall not be advertised for sale in any manner that creates the impression that it is being offered for sale by the manufacturer or distributor of the vehicle. An advertisement shall not contain terms such as “factory sale,” “fleet prices,” “wholesale prices,” “factory approved,” “factory sponsored,” “manufacturer sale,” use a manufacturer's name or abbreviation in any manner calculated or likely to create an impression that the vehicle is being offered for sale by the manufacturer or distributor, or use any other similar terms which indicate sales other than retail sales from the dealer" (43 Tex. Admin. Code § 215.261).
These laws make it illegal to buy a car from Tesla in person, at a Tesla Gallery. Thus, all Texas orders are taken via the internet or over the phone. Texas residents can still easily buy a car from Tesla, but the purchase is handled as an out-of-state transaction. This may mean that the price will not include Texas state sales tax, which instead must be paid when the buyer registers the car with the state. In 2015, Tesla lobbied the [[Texas Legislature]] to modify the law<ref>{{cite web |url=http://txlobby.com/uncategorized/texas-lobbyist-news-tesla-poised-lobbying-blitz-2015/ |title=Tesla Poised for Lobbying Blitz in 2015 |website=Texas Lobby Group, Conservative Lobbyists |date=2015-01-21 |accessdate=2015-08-21}}</ref> to allow Tesla to sell directly to consumers, and specifically allow Tesla employees to discuss "financing, leasing, or purchasing options" at the firm's existing stores in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[Dallas]], and [[Houston]].<ref>{{cite news |last=White |first=Ronald D. |title=Tesla CEO takes dealer fight to Texas, says he can sell more cars |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/autos/la-fi-hy-tesla-ceo-takes-dealer-fight-to-texas-says-he-can-sell-more-cars-20130410,0,1676772.story |accessdate=2013-04-15 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=2013-04-10}}</ref> Texas considered legislation in 2015 to allow Tesla to operate in the state<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.autonews.com/article/20150220/RETAIL07/150229983/tesla-could-open-up-to-12-texas-stores-if-legislation-passes |title=Tesla could open up to 12 Texas stores if legislation passes |first=Hannah |last=Lutz |work=Automotive News |date=2015-01-20 |accessdate=2015-08-21}}</ref> but legislation was not passed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bgr.com/2015/05/20/tesla-sales-texas-model-s/ |title=Tesla Sales Texas: Direct sales of Tesla Model S not coming to Texas |first=Yoni |last=Heisler |website=BGR |date=2015-05-20 |accessdate=2015-08-21}}</ref>
{{asof|2016}}, most of the [[Republican Party of Texas|GOP delegates]] support direct sales while [[Greg_Abbott#Governor_of_Texas|Governor Abbott]] prefers the current system. According to [[Texans for Public Justice]], Tesla spent $1.3m on lobbyists while dealerships spent $1m.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://trailblazersblog.dallasnews.com/2016/05/texas-auto-dealers-receive-tesla-sized-dent-from-state-gop.html/|title=Texas auto dealers receive Tesla-sized dent from state GOP|publisher=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|website=Trail Blazers Blog|accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref>
===Utah=== [[Utah]] also bans direct auto sales. In connection with Tesla's request in 2016 that the [[Utah Supreme Court]] reverse the state's ban on direct auto sales, the automobile dealers filed documents to the court that was interpreted as supporting Tesla's case by stating: 'Tesla builds a car. It has four wheels. You press a pedal with your foot to make it go, and you turn the steering wheel to change direction. That you plug it in rather than gas it up is a trifle'.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.ksl.com/?sid=40787647&nid=157&title=utah-car-dealers-weighing-in-on-tesla-court-fight |title=Utah car dealers weighing in on Tesla court fight |first=Lindsay |last=Whitehurst |work=KSL Broadcasting |location=Salt Lake City |date=2016-07-24 |access-date=2016-07-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= https://electrek.co/2016/07/25/tesla-direct-sales-lawsuit-dealerships-utah/ |title= Tesla Direct Sales Lawsuit: Dealerships argue they could sell Tesla vehicles because ‘they have 4 wheels’ |website= electrek.co |first= Fred |last= Lambert |date= 2016-07-25 |accessdate= 2016-08-21}}</ref> Tesla has a gallery showroom open in Salt Lake City that was originally intended to be a store. In 2017 the Utah Supreme Court upheld the law banning manufacturers from having any controlling interest in an autodealer.<ref>[http://archive.sltrib.com/article.php?id=5135215&itype=CMSID Utah Supreme Court upholds decision saying Tesla subsidiary can't sell its electric cars here], The Salt Lake Tribune, April 4, 2017</ref><ref>[http://kutv.com/news/local/utah-supreme-court-rules-against-tesla-in-push-to-sell-cars Tesla loses at Utah Supreme Court, can't sell directly in state], KUTV, April 3rd 2017</ref>
As of March 2018, H.B. 369 Auto Dealership License Amendments that would allow manufacturer direct sales, has passed the House with no votes against it and passed the Senate with only a single vote against it.<ref>https://le.utah.gov/~2018/bills/static/HB0369.html</ref>
===Connecticut=== [[Connecticut]] does not allow manufacturer direct sales. Tesla operates at gallery in Greenwich that the Connecticut Automotive Retailers Association is attempting to get shut down via a lawsuit. As of March 2018, Tesla is appealing a ruling that they operate the Greenwich gallery as an unlicensed dealership.<ref>[http://civilinquiry.jud.ct.gov/CaseDetail/PublicCaseDetail.aspx?DocketNo=HHBCV176038099S TESLA, INC. v. CONNECTICUT DEPARTMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES Et Al]</ref>
In 2015, 2016, and 2017, bills were introduced in the legislature to allow licensing electric vehicle manufactures as dealers.<ref>[http://www.courant.com/politics/hc-pol-tesla-legislation-20180209-story.html After Four Years Of Trying, Tesla Hopes To Win Approval To Sell Cars In Connecticut], 10 Feb 2018</ref> As of March 2018, H.B. No. 5310 was introduced that would allow manufacturer direct electric vehicle sales.<ref>https://www.cga.ct.gov/asp/cgabillstatus/cgabillstatus.asp?selBillType=Bill&bill_num=HB-5310</ref> The 2018 bill passed the Joint Committee on Transportation on a 25 to 11 vote on 23 March.<ref>https://www.cga.ct.gov/2018/TS/h/2018HB-05310-R00TRA-CV9-TS.htm</ref>
===West Virginia=== [[West Virginia]] does not allow Tesla-owned stores or showrooms.<ref name=ccGA-WV>{{cite news |url=http://www.thecarconnection.com/news/1097489_tesla-wins-in-georgia-loses-in-west-virginia |publisher=[[TheCarConnection.com]] |first=Richard |last=Read |title=Tesla Wins in Georgia, Loses in West Virginia |date=2015-03-27 |accessdate=2015-07-07}}</ref>
===Wisconsin=== A legislative bill is being considered in [[Wisconsin]] to allow only electric vehicle manufactures to sell directly. The bill is opposed by the Wisconsin Automobile Dealers & Truck Association.<ref>[https://www.jsonline.com/story/money/business/2017/11/01/legislation-would-allow-direct-sales-tesla-wisconsin/822821001/ Legislation would let Tesla sell directly to buyers in Wisconsin]</ref>
===Nebraska=== [[Nebraska]] prohibits Tesla direct sales, but Legislative Bill 830 was introduced in 2018 in an attempt to change the law.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-nebraska-bill-support-direct-sales-model/|title=Tesla attends Nebraska hearing in support of new bill for direct sales rights|website=www.teslarati.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-31}}</ref>
===Oklahoma=== [[Oklahoma]] currently bans direct sales by auto manufacturers, but legislation was introduced in February 2018 to attempt to allow it.<ref>[https://legiscan.com/OK/research/SB1560/2018 OK SB1560]</ref>
==States with limited sales==
===Colorado (1 store limit)=== Tesla opened its first and only [[Colorado (state)|Colorado]] store in [[Boulder, Colorado|Boulder]] in 2009. A 2010 revision to the state dealership law removed the word "franchised". This closed the loophole that Tesla had used to open a direct dealership but grandfathered in the existing single store.<ref>[http://www.autonews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20121008/RETAIL07/310089952/dealers-call-tesla-factory-stores-illegal Dealers call Tesla factory stores illegal], Automotive News, Oct 2012</ref> This limitation was supported by the Colorado Automobile Dealers Association.<ref>[http://www.leg.state.co.us/clics/clics2010a/csl.nsf/fsbillcont/F1E54AE218AB9411872576A80026BCE8?Open&file=1049_01.pdf Colorado House Bill 10-1049]</ref><ref>[https://www.denverpost.com/2014/03/12/tesla-motors-limited-to-one-store-in-colorado-and-none-in-new-jersey/ Tesla limited to one store in Colorado]</ref> The store moved from Boulder to the [[Park Meadows]] shopping mall in [[Lone Tree, Colorado|Lone Tree]] in 2011.<ref>[http://www.westword.com/news/tesla-motors-moves-from-boulders-pearl-street-showroom-to-park-meadows-5894577 Tesla Motors moves from Boulder's Pearl Street showroom to Park Meadows]</ref>
Showrooms/galleries have since been opened in Aspen, Vail, and the [[Cherry Creek Shopping Center]] in Denver. There is a service center in Denver and a service center and showroom in Littleton.<ref>[https://www.bizjournals.com/denver/news/2017/08/01/tesla-expands-denver-area-operations.html Tesla expands Denver-area operations], Aug 2017</ref>
A large service center and store is being built in [[Superior, Colorado]] in Boulder County,<ref>[http://www.dailycamera.com/superior-news/ci_31749343/tesla-may-open-shop-superior-boulder-county Tesla to open shop in Superior, heralding company's return to Boulder County], Anthony Hahn, Daily Camera, 20 March 2018</ref> targeted for spring 2019 opening.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Carroll |first1=Rick |title=Tesla zooms out of Aspen, closes showroom on Cooper mall |url=https://www.aspentimes.com/news/local/tesla-zooms-out-of-aspen-closes-showroom-on-cooper-mall/ |website=Aspen Times |accessdate=19 August 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
===North Carolina (second store not allowed)=== Tesla has one store in [[North Carolina]], but the state would not grant Tesla a dealer license for a second location in 2016.<ref>[https://electrek.co/2016/05/25/tesla-north-carolina-direct-sales-dealership-license/ North Carolina walks back on direct sales and denies Tesla’s latest dealership license]</ref> A legislative bill that would allow six Tesla stores was shelved in 2017.<ref>[https://electrek.co/2017/06/23/tesla-direct-sale-bill-north-carolina/ Tesla’s direct-sale bill is shelved in North Carolina]</ref>
===Virginia (2 stores, unclear if more would be denied)=== In Virginia Tesla has obtained license from the [[Department of Motor Vehicles]] (DMV) for a single direct sales dealership ([[Tysons Corner, Virginia|Tysons Corner]]). Upon learning of Tesla's attempt to obtain a second dealership in the state, the Virginia Automobile Dealers Association filed a lawsuit in March 2016 against both Tesla and the DMV to prevent the licensing of the second dealership.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.hybridcars.com/virginia-dealers-protest-teslas-retail-store-moves/ |title= Virginia Dealers Protest Tesla’s Retail Store Moves |website= hybridcars.com |first= Jon |last= LeSage |date= 2016-06-02 |accessdate= 2016-08-21}}</ref> In September 2016, the [[Virginia Department of Motor Vehicles]] (VDMV) recommended ending Tesla direct sales, as at least 11 dealerships were interested in selling Tesla vehicles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.richmond.com/business/local/article_cba531aa-f928-584a-8691-ed42fba636fd.html |title=DMV hearing officer rules against Tesla Motors request for Richmond-area dealership|website=Richmond Times-Dispatch |accessdate= 2016-09-09}}</ref> The VDMV later allowed Tesla to open another shop ([[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]]), as Tesla has no dealerships to compete against;<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-12-01/tesla-wins-right-to-open-virginia-store-in-win-against-dealers |title=Tesla Wins Right to Open Virginia Store in Win Against Dealers|website=Bloomberg.com|accessdate= 2016-12-02}}</ref> the 11 interested dealerships would not be able to compete on undiscounted prices, as Tesla has the same price online and in shops.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/tesla-gets-green-light-for-second-virginia-store/2016/11/30/b9f7d4f6-b73d-11e6-959c-172c82123976_story.html |title=Tesla gets green light for second Virginia store |date=2016-11-30 |website=[[Washington Post]]|accessdate= 2016-12-02 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20161201111351/https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/tesla-gets-green-light-for-second-virginia-store/2016/11/30/b9f7d4f6-b73d-11e6-959c-172c82123976_story.html |archivedate= 2016-12-01 |deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name=vdmv>[https://www.dmv.virginia.gov/commercial/dealer/pdf/tesla_file2016_001.pdf Formal Evidentiary Hearing: Tesla Motors, Inc., File No. 2016-001 - Request for a Hearing Pursuant to Va. Code§§ 46.2-1572(4) and 46.2-1573 to be a Dealer ] [https://web.archive.org/web/20161202171857/https://www.dmv.virginia.gov/commercial/dealer/pdf/tesla_file2016_001.pdf Archive] ''[[Virginia Department of Motor Vehicles]]'', November 30, 2016. Quote: "Tesla sells its vehicles at uniform prices whether a customer purchases through the Tesla website or at a Tesla store. Tesla could not or would not offer “dealer discounts” or “wholesale pricing” on new cars to a prospective dealership. VADA’s own experts agreed that it would be very hard or impossible for a dealership to be profitable unless Tesla offered their cars at wholesale prices." "2015 Consumer Reports survey ranked Tesla service centers number one"</ref> Third-party profits could come from servicing as is traditional, but Tesla already has satisfactory servicing.<ref name=vdmv/><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.consumerreports.org/cro/magazine/2015/03/best-places-to-get-your-car-repaired/index.htm |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160522041427/http://www.consumerreports.org/cro/magazine/2015/03/best-places-to-get-your-car-repaired/index.htm |title=Independent vs. Dealer Shops for Car Repair |date= 2015-01-22 |archivedate= 2016-05-22 |publisher=[[Consumer Reports]] |accessdate=2016-12-02 |deadurl=no |quote= With few exceptions, the entire list of independent shops got high marks on those factors. The same couldn’t be said for franchised new-car dealers. The one automaker that outscored the independent shops was the electric carmaker Tesla, which earned high praise for its on-time repairs, courtesy, price, quality, and overall satisfaction.}}</ref>
The Virginia Automobile Dealers Association continues to use the legal system in an attempt to prevent Tesla from opening more than a single store and is currently appealing the ruling by the Commissioner of the Department of Motor Vehicles allowing the second store to be opened.<ref>[http://www.richmond.com/business/local/judge-auto-dealer-group-s-challenge-of-tesla-store-in/article_f7368be0-1a5d-54e0-b140-6f162430374c.html Judge: Auto dealer group's challenge of Tesla store in Henrico can proceed]</ref><ref>https://caselaw.findlaw.com/va-supreme-court/1889778.html</ref><ref>http://www.richmond.com/business/local/court-challenge-can-proceed-against-dmv-decision-allowing-tesla-store/article_98e1499f-cc2f-5c5d-96b8-5ed507e0a19b.html</ref> The Dealers Association also had state Senators remove a governor-appointed Tesla employee from the Motor Vehicle Dealer Board, created in 1995, that regulates car dealers in the state.<ref>http://www.richmond.com/news/virginia/government-politics/general-assembly/senate-committee-rejects-appointment-of-tesla-employee-to-motor-vehicle/article_8241f9a9-175c-5866-a4e5-2495d2716b18.html</ref>
===New Jersey (4 store limit)=== On March 10, 2014, it was announced that [[New Jersey Motor Vehicle Commission]] and Governor [[Chris Christie]]'s administration would be holding a meeting to pass a new proposal into law. This new proposal, PRN 2013-138, was announced one day before it was to be put into law. Tesla responded by saying that the proposal "seeks to impose stringent licensing rules that would, among other things, require all new motor vehicles to be sold through middlemen and block Tesla's direct sales model," and that "[Governor Christie's] Administration has decided to go outside the legislative process by expediting a rule proposal that would completely change the law in New Jersey."<ref name=Business>{{Cite news |title=Tesla Goes To War Against Chris Christie |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-motors-vs-chris-christie-2014-3 |date=2014-03-11 |first=Hunter |last=Walker |publisher=[[Business Insider]] |agency=Business Insider.com |accessdate=2014-03-11}}</ref> The law was passed, and "Tesla will no longer [be able to] sell electric cars in New Jersey, effective April 1". Diarmuid O'Connell, Tesla Vice President of Business Development, said, "Worse, it has done so without any reasonable notice or even a public hearing."<ref>{{Cite news |title=New Jersey bans direct auto sales |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/101481668 |date=2014-03-11 |first=Hunter |last=Walker |publisher=[[Business Insider]] |agency=Business Insider.com |accessdate=2014-03-11}}</ref> ''[[Forbes]]'' contributor Mark Rogosky said, "The state's new rules protect its auto dealers from having to compete with Tesla's direct sales model"; he points out that this is a direct contrast from what Christie said earlier, "We are for a free-market society that allows your effort and ingenuity to determine your success, not the cold, hard hand of the government."<ref>{{Cite news |title=In New Jersey, Tesla Crashes into The Hypocrisy of Chris Christie |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/markrogowsky/2014/03/11/in-new-jersey-tesla-crashes-into-the-hypocrisy-of-chris-christie/ |date=2014-03-11 |first=Mark |last=Rogosky |work=[[Forbes]] |accessdate=2014-03-11}}</ref> Kevin Roberts, a spokesman for the Christie administration, responded by saying "it was the [Tesla Motors] company, not the governor's office, that was attempting to bypass normal procedures.".<ref name=Business/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/tesla-motors-inc-direct-sales-new-jersey-legislature-passes-measure-allow-model-s-1848804 |title=Tesla Motors Inc Direct Sales in New Jersey: Legislature Passes Measure To Allow Model S Sales Outside Of Dealer Franchise System; Will Gov. Christie Block The Bill? |first=Angelo |last=Young |date=2015-03-16 |website=International Business Times |accessdate=2015-07-16}}</ref> In March 2015, the ban on Tesla Motor's operations in New Jersey was lifted, but with restrictions (maximum of 4 locations, and 1 service center).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.app.com/story/news/politics/new-jersey/2015/03/18/tesla-sales-nj-christie-signs-law/24968635/ |title=Christie signs law allowing Tesla sales in New Jersey |first=Michael |last=Symons |work=Asbury Park Press |date=2015-03-18 |accessdate=2015-08-21}}</ref>
===Maryland (4 store limit)=== In May 2015, [[Maryland]] approved, through House Bill 235,<ref>[http://mgaleg.maryland.gov/webmga/frmMain.aspx?pid=billpage&stab=01&id=hb0235&tab=subject3&ys=2015RS HB0235], General Assembly of Maryland</ref> direct Tesla sales to customers beginning in October 2015, though limiting the statewide number of stores to only four. The legislation was crafted specifically for Tesla and allows only four manufacturers of electric or non-fossil fuel burning vehicles without existing franchisees to be licensed to sell direct to the public.<ref>Angelo Young. "[http://www.ibtimes.com/tesla-motors-inc-tsla-wins-approval-direct-car-sales-maryland-starting-october-1-1918655 Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Wins Approval For Direct Car Sales In Maryland, Starting October 1]"</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thecarconnection.com/news/1097872_tesla-triumphs-in-maryland-as-new-bill-allows-sales-at-four-sites-which-state-is-next |title=Tesla Triumphs in Maryland As New Bill Allows Sales at Four Sites: Which State Is Next? |author=Richard Read |website=The Car Connection |accessdate=2015-07-16}}</ref> <!-- Florida? -->
===Pennsylvania (5 store limit)=== Pennsylvania enacted a law in 2014 that allows Tesla to open up to five stores.<ref>[http://www.autonews.com/article/20140711/RETAIL/140719962/tesla-cleared-to-open-up-to-5-stores-in-pa.-under-new-law Tesla cleared to open up to 5 stores in Pa. under new law], July 11, 2014</ref>
===New York (5 store limit)=== In 2014, [[New York (state)|New York]] banned direct sales but grandfathered in five Tesla stores.<ref>[https://nypost.com/2014/03/28/cuomo-brokers-deal-to-keep-tesla-stores-open/ Cuomo brokers deal to keep Tesla stores open], March 28, 2014</ref><ref name=electrek2017-05-25>{{cite web|url= https://electrek.co/2017/05/25/tesla-store-connecticut-dealership/ |title=Tesla promises 10 stores in Connecticut by next year and dealerships warn of 10% job cuts in lobbying for direct sales |first=Fred |last=Lambert |date= 2017-05-25 |website=Electrek |publisher=|accessdate= 2017-05-25 }}</ref> Tesla operates two galleries in addition to its five stores.
There is proposed legislation (Senate bill S6600A and Assembly bill A8248A) to allow more stores. The Eastern New York Coalition of Automotive Retailers is opposed to this as is the Rochester Automobile Dealers Association.<ref>[https://www.bizjournals.com/albany/news/2018/03/01/tesla-could-open-15-new-stores-including-one-in.html Tesla could open 15 new stores, including one in Albany, under proposed state legislation]</ref>
===Georgia (5 store limit)=== Since 2015, [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] law no longer restricts Tesla to 150 car sales per year but limits sales to five locations.<ref name=ccGA-WV/><ref>[https://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/blog/capitol_vision/2015/03/general-assembly-oks-tesla-bill.html General Assembly OKs Tesla bill], Atlanta Business Chronicle, 25 March 2015</ref>
==States for which Tesla gained the right to mostly unrestricted direct sales== ===New Hampshire (2013 law change)=== In 2013, [[New Hampshire]] passed legislation to allow auto manufacturers with no existing franchise dealer in the state to engage in direct sales.<ref>[http://www.leftlanenews.com/new-hampshire-to-allow-tesla-others-to-sell-cars-direct-to-consumers.html New Hampshire to allow Tesla, others to sell cars direct to consumers], June 26, 2013</ref>
===Minnesota (2013 law interpretation)=== The Minnesota Department of Public Safety ruled in 2013 that the original dealer law "does not prohibit a manufacturer from becoming licensed as a dealer in Minnesota".<ref>[http://www.startribune.com/minnesota-sales-of-electric-gas-cars-collide/197706621/ Minnesota sales of electric, gas cars collide], Star Tribune, March 13, 2013</ref> The dealership association in the state failed in their attempt to get the law changed to block Tesla.<ref>[http://www.autonews.com/article/20130312/RETAIL07/130319974/minnesota-dealers-drop-tesla-fight-for-now Minnesota dealers drop Tesla fight for now], Automotive News, March 12, 2013</ref>
===Washington (2014 law)=== A 2014 [[Washington (state)|Washington]] state law outlawed direct sales but grandfathered in Tesla.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/autos-tesla-lobbying/in-washington-state-tesla-finds-way-to-share-the-road-with-dealers-idUSL2N0MF1Z020140321 In Washington state, Tesla finds way to share the road with dealers], Mar 21, 2014</ref><ref>https://www.geekwire.com/2014/tesla-wins-battle-auto-dealers-washington-state-future-rivals-screwed/</ref>
===Massachusetts (2014 court ruling)=== After an almost two year court battle with the [[Massachusetts]] State Automobile Dealers Association, a September 2014 ruling by the [[Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court]] allowed Tesla to begin selling directly in the state.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/240088155/Massachusetts-State-Automobile-Dealers-v-Tesla|title=Massachusetts State Automobile Dealers v Tesla - Franchising - Standing (Law)|website=Scribd}}</ref><ref name=bostin>{{cite news |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2014/09/15/sjc-rules-for-tesla-fight-with-car-dealers/tFMtsQT4Ta4LI3RgcrOJOP/story.html |title=SJC rules for Tesla in fight with car dealers |work=Boston Globe |date=2014-09-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2014/09/17/Tesla-wins-battle-over-dealerships-in-Massachusetts/2131410978187/ |title=Court: Tesla can sell direct to customers in Mass |first=Gabrielle |last=Levy |date=2014-09-17 |website=UPI |accessdate=2017-01-17 }}</ref>
===Missouri (2017 court ruling)=== A [[Missouri Circuit Courts|Missouri circuit court]] ruled in August 2016 to end direct sales,<ref name=mo2016-09>{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/tesla-vows-to-keep-selling-cars-directly-to-missouri-consumers-2016-09-08 |title=Tesla vows to keep selling cars directly to Missouri consumers |website=MarketWatch |date= 2016-09-08 |accessdate= 2016-09-08}}</ref> confirmed in late December 2016,<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.stltoday.com/business/local/tesla-s-license-to-sell-cars-in-missouri-expiring/article_b4f52be1-3df6-59ba-9455-73a9657ad865.html |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20161230195454/http://www.stltoday.com/business/local/tesla-s-license-to-sell-cars-in-missouri-expiring/article_b4f52be1-3df6-59ba-9455-73a9657ad865.html |title=Tesla's license to sell cars in Missouri expiring|first=Lisa |last=Brown |date= 2016-12-30 |archivedate= 2016-12-30 |website=stltoday.com|accessdate= 2016-12-30 |deadurl=no |quote=a single entity may not manufacture vehicles for sale in Missouri and possess a Missouri new motor vehicle dealer license}}</ref> and [[Stay of proceedings|delayed]] in early January<!--4 or 5?--> while the [[Missouri Department of Revenue]] [[appeal]]s the former verdict.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/news/2017/01/05/appeals-court-rules-on-tesla-sales-in-missouri.html |title=Appeals court rules on Tesla sales in Missouri |last=Feldt |first=Brian |date=2017-01-05 |website= |publisher= |access-date=2017-01-05 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20170105214125/http://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/news/2017/01/05/appeals-court-rules-on-tesla-sales-in-missouri.html |archive-date=2017-01-05 |dead-url= no |quote=}}</ref> In December 2017 an appeals court reversed the circuit court's decision, saying the Missouri Automobile Dealers Association did not have [[standing (law)|standing]] to sue.<ref>[http://kcur.org/post/missouri-appeals-court-hands-win-electric-car-maker-tesla Missouri Appeals Court Hands Win To Electric Car Maker Tesla], [[KCUR]], 5 Dec 2017</ref>
===Wyoming (2017 law change)=== [[Wyoming]] banned direct sales until a law change in 2017 that created a direct sale manufacturer's license.<ref>[http://trib.com/news/state-and-regional/govt-and-politics/legislature-passes-a-bill-that-would-allow-tesla-to-open/article_c35d1d64-3392-5bad-837a-adefbd3f7927.html Legislature passes a bill that would allow Tesla to open showroom, service shop in Wyoming], Casper Star Tribune</ref><ref>https://openstates.org/wy/bills/2017/SF57/</ref> Electric cars were seen as a way to promote the use of [[coal]] mined in the state.
===Arizona (2017 court ruling)=== [[Arizona]] blocked direct sales until June 2017 when an administrative law judge ruled that the Arizona Department of Transportation interpreted the law incorrectly. This was after a years legal long battle by Tesla.<ref>[https://www.azcentral.com/story/money/business/tech/2017/06/22/tesla-selling-electric-cars-scottsdale-store-arizona/416527001/ Yes, you can buy a Tesla electric car at its Scottsdale store]</ref>
===Indiana (2017 law change)=== [[Indiana]] allows a service center<ref>{{cite web|url= https://electrek.co/2016/09/16/tesla-gets-a-service-center-with-an-expiration-date-in-indiana/ |title=Tesla gets a service center with an expiration date in Indiana|website=Electrek |accessdate=2016-09-16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibj.com/blogs/3-property-lines/post/60370-tesla-to-open-first-indy-service-center|title=Tesla to open first Indy service center|publisher=}}</ref> and manufacturer sales for 30 months, ending direct Tesla sales by the end of 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2016/02/22/tesla-anti-store-gm-bill-indiana/ |title=Tesla fights back against anti-store bill 'authored and pushed' by GM |first=Sebastian |last=Blanco |work=Autoblog |date=2016-02-22 |access-date=2016-02-23}}</ref> A legislative proposal had further restrictions,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://iga.in.gov/legislative/2017/bills/house/1592#document-55fe0e6c|title=House Bill 1592 - Automobile sales requirements|first=Indiana General|last=Assembly|website=Indiana General Assembly}}</ref> opposed by Tesla.<ref>https://freemarketindiana.com/</ref> The Roads and Transportation committee approved a modification that grandfathered Tesla, but maintained the ban on all new direct sales by other automakers.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://electrek.co/2017/02/02/tesla-indiana-grandfathered-in-ban/ |title=Tesla escapes ban in Indiana by being 'grandfathered in', but the state moves forward with ban on direct sales |first=Fred |last=Lambert |date=2017-02-02|website=Electrek |accessdate=2017-02-02}}</ref>
===Rhode Island (2017)=== In December 2017, Tesla was granted a license by the state of Rhode Island after DMV lawyers concluded that the law blocking direct auto sales only applied to manufactures that have franchise dealers. Tesla plans to begin sales in 2018.<ref>[http://www.providencejournal.com/news/20180110/electric-car-manufacturer-tesla-granted-licenses-to-sell-direct-in-ri Electric car manufacturer Tesla granted licenses to sell direct in R.I.]</ref>
===Utah (2018 law change)=== As of March 21st, 2018, Utah Governor Herbert signed into law allowing Tesla direct sales in the state.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://universe.byu.edu/2018/04/19/tesla-enters-utah-market-as-more-drivers-switch-to-electric/|title=Tesla enters Utah market as more drivers switch to electric - The Daily Universe|date=2018-04-19|work=The Daily Universe|access-date=2018-06-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Surveys== In 2014, [[Consumer Reports]] performed a [[Mystery shopping|mystery shopper]] survey of 19 secret shoppers in 85 dealerships, querying electric vehicles (EV). Most shoppers found it to be a positive experience, although 35 dealerships recommended petrol cars instead, and 13 discouraged EVs. The most knowledgeable dealerships were Chevrolet, and the least were Toyota.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.consumerreports.org/cro/news/2014/04/dealers-not-always-plugged-in-about-electric-cars-secret-shopper-study-reveals/index.htm |title=Dealership Survey - Electric Cars |publisher=[[Consumer Reports]] |date=2014-04-22 |accessdate=2016-08-22 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170130230407/http://www.consumerreports.org/cro/news/2014/04/dealers-not-always-plugged-in-about-electric-cars-secret-shopper-study-reveals/index.htm |archivedate=2017-01-30 |deadurl=no}}</ref><!--"Still, even at the least knowledgeable dealership visited for this project, our secret shopper said they felt positive about the experience overall"-->
In 2016, two shopper surveys showed contrasting shopping experiences between Tesla and traditional dealerships. One performed by the [[environmental organization]] [[Sierra Club]] found that in 14% of traditional dealerships, their electric cars were not charged to test drive, and 33% did not discuss [[Government_incentives_for_plug-in_electric_vehicles#United_States|$7,500 tax credits]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://content.sierraclub.org/press-releases/2016/08/first-ever-multi-state-study-electric-vehicle-shopping-experience |title=First-Ever Multi-State Study on Electric Vehicle Shopping Experience|website=Sierra Club National |accessdate=2016-08-15 }}</ref><ref name=mo2016-09/>
Another study by industry analyst Pied Piper using mystery shoppers found that Tesla sales stores (not galleries) differed among each other on sales techniques, and many stores were reluctant to engage in [[Closing (sales)|closing a sale]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://wardsauto.com/dealer/mystery-shoppers-put-tesla-dealerships-cellar-again |title=Mystery Shoppers Put Tesla Dealerships in Cellar – Again|publisher=[[Ward's]] |accessdate=15 August 2016 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160712124336/http://wardsauto.com/dealer/mystery-shoppers-put-tesla-dealerships-cellar-again |archivedate=2016-07-12 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
Customers generally view car shopping as a challenging experience.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/1654/honesty-ethics-professions.aspx|title=Honesty/Ethics in Professions|first=Gallup,|last=Inc.|publisher=}}</ref>

{{For|the 1983 collection of Gordon R. Dickson stories|The Man from Earth (short story collection)}} {{Infobox film | name = The Man from Earth | image = The Man from Earth.png | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Richard Schenkman]] | producer = {{plainlist| * Emerson Bixby * Eric D. Wilkinson * Richard Schenkman * [[Steven Alexander]] }} | writer = [[Jerome Bixby]] | music = Mark Hinton Stewart | starring = {{plainlist| * [[David Lee Smith]] * [[John Billingsley]] * [[Tony Todd]] }} | distributor = {{plainlist| * [[Anchor Bay Entertainment]] * [[Shoreline Entertainment]] }} | released = {{Film date|2007|11|13}} | runtime = 89 minutes | language = English | country = United States | budget = $200,000<ref name = "latimes"/> }} '''''The Man from Earth''''' is a 2007 American [[drama film|drama]] [[science fiction film]] written by [[Jerome Bixby]] and directed by [[Richard Schenkman]]. It stars [[David Lee Smith]] as John Oldman, the protagonist. The screenplay was conceived by Jerome Bixby in the early 1960s and completed on his deathbed in April 1998.<ref name = "promotional site">{{cite web | title = The Man From Earth (About) | work = Manfromearth.com | url = http://www.manfromearth.com/ManFromEarth-About.html | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121228142327/http://www.manfromearth.com/ManFromEarth-About.html| archivedate=2012-12-28 | accessdate = 2015-11-29}}</ref> The film gained recognition in part for being widely distributed through Internet [[peer-to-peer]] networks, which raised its profile. The film was later adapted by Schenkman into a stage play of the same name.
The plot focuses on John Oldman, a departing university professor, who claims to be a [[Cro-Magnon]] (or [[Magdalenian]] caveman) who has secretly survived for more than 14,000 years. The entire film is set in and around Oldman's house during his farewell party and is composed almost entirely of dialogue. The plot advances through intellectual arguments between Oldman and his fellow faculty members.
==Plot== Professor John Oldman is packing his belongings onto his truck, preparing to move to a new home. His colleagues show up to give him an impromptu farewell party: Harry, a biologist; Edith, an [[art history]] professor and devout [[Christian]]; Dan ([[Tony Todd]]), an [[anthropologist]]; Sandy, a [[historian]] who is in love with John; Dr. Will Gruber, a psychiatrist; Art, an archaeologist; and his student Linda.
As John's colleagues press him to explain the reason for his departure, he slowly, and somewhat reluctantly, reveals that he is a prehistoric [[caveman]] who has lived for more than 14 millennia, and that he relocates every ten years to keep others from realizing that [[immortality|he does not age]]. He begins his tale under the guise of a possible science-fiction story, but eventually stops speaking in hypotheticals and begins answering questions from a first-person perspective. His colleagues refuse to believe his story. John continues his tale, relating how he was a [[Sumer]]ian for 2000 years, a [[Babylonia]]n, and eventually went east to become a disciple of [[Gautama Buddha]]. He claims to have been given a chance to sail with [[Christopher Columbus]] (admitting that at the time he [[Myth of the flat Earth|still believed the earth was flat]]) and to have befriended [[Vincent van Gogh|Van Gogh]] (one of whose original paintings he apparently owns, a gift from the artist himself).
In the course of the conversation, each of John's colleagues questions his story based on knowledge from his or her own academic specialty. Harry, the [[biologist]], struggles with how biology could allow for the possibility of a human being living for so long. Art, the [[archaeologist]], questions John about events in [[prehistory]]. He exclaims that John's answers, though correct, could have come from any textbook; John rejoins that, like any human, his memory is imperfect and he only sees events from his own narrow perspective, so he is not all-knowing. Will, the [[psychiatrist]], questions if John feels guilt for outliving everyone he has ever known and loved, and threatens John with a gun (which is later revealed to have been unloaded) before temporarily leaving. John then learns from the group that Will's wife had died the previous day after a long illness.
The discussion turns to the topic of religion. John mentions that he is not a follower of a particular religion; though he does not necessarily believe in an omnipotent God, he does not discount the possibility of such a being's existence. Pressed by the group, John reluctantly reveals that in trying to take Buddha's teachings to the west, into the [[eastern Roman Empire]], he became the inspiration for the [[Life of Jesus in the New Testament|Jesus story]]. After this revelation, emotions in the room run high. Edith begins crying. Will demands that John end his tale and give the group a sense of closure by admitting it was all a hoax, and threatens to have John involuntarily committed for psychiatric evaluation should he refuse to do so. John appears to ruminate over his response before finally "confessing" to everyone that his story was a prank.
John's friends leave the party with various reactions: Edith is relieved; Harry and Dan indicate an open mind; Art never wants to see John again; Will still believes John is mad and still wants him committed; Sandy and Linda clearly believe John. After everyone else but Will and Sandy have left, Will overhears John and Sandy's conversation, which suggests the story could be true after all. John mentions some of the [[pseudonym]]s he has used over the years, and Will realizes one was his father's name. He asks John questions that only his father could answer and, when John does answer correctly, Will is shocked before having emotional breakdown, suffers a heart attack and dies in their arms. After the body has been taken away, Sandy realizes this is the first time John has seen one of his grown children die. John wordlessly gets in his truck and starts to drive to an unknown destination. Then he stops and waits for Sandy, who walks over to the truck.
==Cast== In order of appearance: * [[David Lee Smith]] as John Oldman * [[Tony Todd]] as Dan * [[John Billingsley]] as Harry * [[Ellen Crawford]] as Edith * [[Annika Peterson]] as Sandy * [[William Katt]] as Art Jenkins * [[Alexis Thorpe]] as Linda Murphy * [[Richard Riehle]] as Dr. Will Gruber * [[Robbie Bryan]] as Police Officer
==Production== The story is [[Jerome Bixby]]'s last work, which he completed on his deathbed in April 1998. Bixby dictated the last of his screenplay to his son, screenwriter Emerson Bixby. After Jerome Bixby's death, the script was given to Richard Schenkman to direct on a $200,000 budget.<ref name = "latimes">{{cite news | last = Fernandez | first = Jay A. | coauthors = | title = A sci-fi writer's final words are brought to life | work = | pages = | language = | publisher = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date = 2007-07-25 | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2007/07/25/calendar/et-scriptland25 | accessdate = 2008-01-07}}</ref>
==Release and marketing== The film screened at the San Diego [[Comic-Con International|Comic-Con]] Film Festival in July 2007, and premiered theatrically in [[Hemet, California]], and [[Pitman, New Jersey]],<ref>[http://blog.nj.com/southjerseylife/2007/11/now_in_theaters.html Movie producer from Newfield releases sci-fi film November 1, 2007 by Senitra Horbrook at [[Gloucester County Times]]].</ref> in October 2007. It was released on DVD in North America by [[Anchor Bay Entertainment]] on November 13, 2007, and became available for digital rental and sale at [[iTunes]] on September 22, 2009. It won the grand prize for Best Screenplay and first place for Best Feature at the [[Rhode Island Film Festival]] in August 2007.<ref name = "startrek">{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = "Jerome Bixby's The Man from Earth" on DVD Nov. 13 | work = | pages = | language = | publisher = StarTrek.com / [[CBS|CBS Studios]], Inc. | date = 2007-10-26 | url = http://www.startrek.com/startrek/view/news/ENT/article/2311423.html | accessdate = 2008-01-07}}</ref>
===Publicity through filesharing=== Producer [[Eric D. Wilkinson]] has publicly thanked users of [[BitTorrent (protocol)|BitTorrent]] who have distributed the film without express permission, saying that it has lifted the profile of the film far beyond the financier's expectations;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://torrentfreak.com/producer-thanks-pirates-for-stealing-his-film-071113/ |title=Producer Thanks Pirates For Stealing His Film |publisher=TorrentFreak |date=2007-11-13 |accessdate=2012-03-24}}</ref> he encouraged fans to purchase the DVD or donate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rlslog.net/piracy-isnt-that-bad-and-they-know-it/ |title=Piracy isn’t THAT bad and they know it |publisher=RLSLOG.net |date= |accessdate=2012-03-24}}</ref>
==Reception== [[IGN]] gave it an 8 out of 10, calling it "intellectual sci-fi".<ref>{{cite web|last=Teh|first=Hock|title=The Man From Earth DVD Review|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/11/06/the-man-from-earth-dvd-review|work=IGN.com|accessdate=2 June 2013|date=November 6, 2007}}</ref> [[DVD Verdict]] criticized the heavy-handed ending, saying that one's opinion of the film would be shaped by views on religion.<ref>{{cite web|last=Stewart|first=James A.|title=The Man From Earth|url=http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/manfromearth.php|work=DVD Verdict|accessdate=2 June 2013|date=November 13, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071118072242/http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/manfromearth.php|archivedate=18 November 2007|df=}}</ref>
===Awards=== The film has been nominated for and won numerous awards.<ref>[http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view&friendID=146843614&blogID=431768935 The Man from Earth ] MySpace Blogs</ref>
* 2007 – WINNER – 1st place – Best Screenplay - [[Rhode Island International Film Festival]] * 2007 – WINNER – Grand Prize - Best Screenplay - Rhode Island International Film Festival<ref>http://www.film-festival.org/awards07.php</ref> * 2008 – WINNER – Best Film – Montevideo Fantastic Film Festival of Uruguay * 2008 – WINNER – Audience Choice Award Montevideo Fantastic Film Festival of Uruguay * 2008 – WINNER – Best Director - Fantaspoa – International Fantastic Film Festival of Porto Alegre, Brazil * 2008 – WINNER – 2ND place – Best Screenplay - Rio de Janeiro International Fantastic Film Festival (RioFan) * 2008 – WINNER – Audience Award: Best Screenplay Film – Fixion-Sars Horror & Fantastic Film Festival of Santiago, Chile * 2008 – WINNER – Jury Award: Best Screenplay – Fixion-Sars Horror & Fantastic Film Festival of Santiago, Chile * 2008 – WINNER – Best SCI-FI Screenplay - International Horror & Sci-Fi Film Festival, Phoenix, AZ * 2008 – WINNER – Best Screenplay - [[Buenos Aires Rojo Sangre]] – Int'l Independent Horror, Fantasy & Bizarre, Argentina * 2007 – [[Saturn Award]] nominee - Best DVD Release - The Man From Earth<ref>[http://www.manfromearth.com/ The Man from Earth official website], top left</ref> * 2008 – WINNER – DVD Critics Award – Best Non-Theatrical Movie
==Soundtrack== All music performed by [[Mark Hinton Stewart]].
* "[[Symphony No. 7 (Beethoven)|7th Symphony - 2nd Movement]]" - Written by [[Ludwig van Beethoven]] * "Forever" **Lyrics by Richard Schenkman **Music by Mark Hinton Stewart **Performed by Mark Hinton Stewart and Chantelle Duncan **Copyright - BDI Music LTD.
==Play== In 2012, Richard Schenkman adapted the film to a play, which received positive reviews.<ref name="September 05, 2012">{{cite news|last=Isenberg|first=Robert|title=The Man From Earth|url=http://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/the-man-from-earth/Content?oid=1561929|accessdate=2 June 2013|newspaper=Pittsburgh City Paper}}</ref>
The theater play was also staged in Greece in 2013 [https://www.athinorama.gr/theatre/performance/the_man_from_earth-10030474.html].
==Sequels== {{main article|The Man from Earth: Holocene}} A sequel, ''[[The Man from Earth: Holocene]]'' was released in 2017. Filming began on June 2, 2016 and ended on June 16. The producers have stated on Facebook that it may be the first in a series.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/ManFromEarthHolocene/|title=The Man From Earth: Holocene {{!}} Facebook|website=www.facebook.com|access-date=2016-09-06}}</ref>
This followed two previous attempts at producing sequels. A [[Kickstarter]] campaign to crowdfund a sequel named ''The Man From Earth II: Man From Earth Millennium'' was announced in September 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wegotthiscovered.com/movies/man-earth-ii-man-earth-millennium-launches-kickstarter-campaign/|title=The Man From Earth II: Man From Earth Millennium Launches Kickstarter Campaign|last=Lowe|first=Alexander|work=We Got This Covered|date=2013-10-02|accessdate=2015-05-24}}</ref> but it was not able to collect the minimum-required supporting by October 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1759006687/the-man-from-earth-ii-man-from-earth-millennium|title=The Man From Earth II: Man From Earth Millennium|work=[[Kickstarter]]|accessdate=2015-05-24}}</ref> Another attempt was then made to crowdfund a series, ''Man From Earth: The Series'', based on the film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wegotthiscovered.com/movies/man-from-earth-the-series-kickstarter-campaign/|title=Man From Earth: The Series Gets A Kickstarter Campaign|last=Lowe|first=Alexander|work=We Got This Covered|date=2014-07-24|accessdate=2015-05-24}}</ref> The second crowd-funding effort completed successfully in August 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1759006687/man-from-earth-the-series/posts/960935|title=Kickstarter campaign for Man from Earth the Series|work=[[Kickstarter]]|accessdate=2015-05-24}}</ref>

In [[phonology]], the '''ts–ch merger''' is the [[merger (phonology)|merger]] of the [[voiceless alveolar affricate]] {{IPA|/ts/}} and the [[voiceless postalveolar affricate]] {{IPA|/tʃ/}}.
In [[Russian language|Russian]], it is the merger of the consonants rendered by letters [[Che (Cyrillic)|Che]] and [[Tse (Cyrillic)|Tse]]. If the shift is towards Tse, it is called ''tsokanye'' ({{lang-ru|цоканье}}); the shift towards Che is called ''chokanye'' ({{lang-ru|чоканье}}).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philol.msu.ru/~dialect/pict/color_16s.gif|accessdate=|language=ru|title=Карта. Различение или совпадение согласных на месте ''ч'' и ''ц''|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/657otyy72|archivedate=2012-02-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philol.msu.ru/~dialect/auxy.php?ty=sng&id=164|accessdate=|language=ru|title=Легенда карты. Различение или совпадение согласных на месте ''ч'' и ''ц''|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/657oumP6p|archivedate=2012-02-01}}</ref>
It is a regular [[sound change]] of [[Lower Sorbian]], but not [[Upper Sorbian]], as seen in the difference between Lower Sorbian {{lang|dsb|[[wikt:cas#Lower Sorbian|cas]]}} and Upper Sorbian {{lang|hsb|[[wikt:čas#Upper Sorbian|čas]]}}, both meaning "time".
In [[Polish language]] the {{IPA|/tʃ/ → /ts/}} merger is part of a more general [[dialect]]al feature called ''[[Mazurzenie]]'' present in many Polish dialects, named for the [[Masovian dialect]].<ref name=koerner>Stanislaw Gogolewski, "Dialectology in Poland, 1873-1997", In: ''Towards a History of Linguistics in Poland'', by E. F. K. Koerner, A. J. Szwedek (eds.) (2001) {{ISBN|90-272-4591-6}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=CTtT7-JTwioC&pg=PA128&dq=mazurzenie p. 128]</ref>
It also occurs in a few areas of the Chakavian dialect of [[Croatian language|Croatian]], known as ''[[Chakavian dialect#Non-palatal tsakavism|tsakavism]]''.
The ''[[sabesdiker losn]]'' feature of [[Northeastern Yiddish]] includes the {{IPA|/tʃ/ → /ts/}} merger.

[[Image:Westford Knight location.JPG|200px|right|thumb|The Westford Knight, shown along Depot Street in Westford, Massachusetts]] [[File:Westford Knight detail.JPG|200px|right|thumb|A detail of the rock, showing the "sword". The "shield" has been painted on, supposedly to indicate an underlying carving]]
'''"Westford Knight"''' is the name given to a pattern, variously interpreted as a carving or a natural feature, or a combination of both, located on a glacial boulder (also known as the '''Sinclair Rock''') in [[Westford, Massachusetts|Westford]], [[Massachusetts]] in the United States.
It is notable for being the subject of popular or [[pseudohistory|pseudohistorical]] speculation on [[Pre-Columbian trans-oceanic contact theories|Pre-Columbian trans-oceanic contact]]. The pattern was first described as a possible Native American carving in 1873. The identification as a "medieval knight" dates to 1954.
==Early references== The rock and carving is first mentioned in print in an 1873 addition of the "Gazetteer of Massachusetts" and was described as "There upon its face a rude figure, supposed to have been cut by some Indian Artist."<ref>Gazetteer of Massachusetts, 1873 page 542</ref> In an 1883 town history, the carving is described as "A broad ledge which crops out near the house of William Kitteredge has upon its surface grooves made by glaciers. Rude outlines of the human face have been traced upon it, and the figure is said to be the work of Indians."<ref>Reverend Edwin R. Hodgman, ''History of the Town of Westford, Mass 1659–1883'' (Lowell, Mass.: Westford Town History Association, 1883).</ref> The carving was subsequently identified as a broken Norse Sword by William Goodwin in his book on the [[America's Stonehenge]] site.<ref>William B. Goodwin, ''The Ruins of Great Ireland in New England'' (Boston: Meador Publishing Company, 1946).</ref>
Frank Glynn, president of the Archaeological Society of Connecticut, re-located the carving and following discussions with [[T. C. Lethbridge]] about Goodwin's theory, chalked in a full figure in 1954, resembling a medieval knight, with a sword and shield, and he is usually said to be the "discoverer of the Westford Knight."<ref>For example, in Richard White, ''These Stones Bear Witness'', page 93 (Anchor House, 2010). {{ISBN|978-1-4520-1718-1}}</ref> It was Lethbridge who suggested to Glynn that the sword was not of Viking origin, but was "a hand-and-a-half wheel pommel sword" common in 14th century North Britain.<ref>Richard White, pages 87-88.</ref>
==Contemporary pseudoarchaeology== The current{{year needed|date=February 2015}} interpretation by those who advocate that the feature on the rock is a human figure is that it commemorates a fallen member of the party of [[Henry I Sinclair, Earl of Orkney|Henry Sinclair]], a [[Scotland|Scottish]] Earl from [[Orkney]], whom some believe to have made a voyage to the New World in 1398, traveling to [[Nova Scotia]] and [[New England]].<ref>Tim Wallace-Murphy, Marilyn Hopkins ''Templars in America: From the Crusades to the New World'' (Weiser Books, 2004)</ref> According to Raymond Ramsey in 1972, the shield carried by the knight in the image was found to support this belief, when "English heraldic experts consulted by Lethbridge definitely identified arms on the shield as belonging to the Sinclairs of Scotland".<ref>Raymond H. Ramsey, ''No Longer on the Map: Discovering Places That Never Were'', pages 65-66 (New York: The Viking Press, 1972). {{ISBN|0-6705-1433-0}}</ref> Usually{{clarify|date=February 2015}} it is claimed that the knight is [[James Gunn (explorer)|Sir James Gunn]], a member of [[Clan Gunn]] and a [[Knights Templar|Knight Templar]] who reportedly traveled with Sinclair.<ref>Steven Sora, ''The Lost Colony of The Templars: Verrazano's Secret Mission To America'', page 161 (Destiny Books, 2004). {{ISBN|978-1-59477-870-4}}</ref> The monument next to the "knight" commemorates this interpretation, stating as fact that Sinclair and his party traveled to present-day [[Massachusetts]]. Believers in this theory often{{clarify|date=February 2015}} cite the [[Newport Tower (Rhode Island)|Newport Tower]] in [[Newport, Rhode Island]] as further evidence to support their claim.<ref>[[Christopher Knight (author)|Christopher Knight]], [[Robert Lomas]], ''[[The Hiram Key]]: Pharaohs, Freemasons and The Discovery of The Secret Scrolls of Jesus'' (London: Century, 1996). {{ISBN|0-7126-8579-0}}</ref>
The theory has no credibility in scholarship.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} It was mentioned in an ''Encyclopedia of Dubious Archaeology'' in 2010.<ref>[[Kenneth L. Feder]], ''Encyclopedia of Dubious Archaeology: From Atlantis To The Walam Olum'', pages 270-271 (Greenwood, 2010). {{ISBN|978-0-313-37919-2}}</ref>
A recent{{year needed|date=February 2015}}<ref>This surfaced in 1995 and never went to print</ref> investigation of the rock by David K. Schafer, Curatorial Assistant for Archaeology at the [[Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology]] at [[Harvard University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ramtops.co.uk/westford.html|title=The Westford Knight Revealed|work=ramtops.co.uk|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> concluded that except for the "sword handle", which is definitely a punch carving, the entire feature consists of naturally formed scratches caused by glaciation. The local town historian of Westford{{who|date=February 2015}}{{year needed|date=February 2015}} has stated that there is evidence that the T-shaped inscription was made in the late 19th century. There are some historians{{who|date=February 2015}} who believe that the area around the rock has undergone erosion since the clearing of trees in the 18th century, and that during the time of the alleged voyage by Sinclair, the rock may have been in a hardwood forest covered by {{convert|3|or|4|ft|m|abbr=on}} of earth.{{refimprove-inline|date=April 2016}} There are some historians{{who|date=February 2015}} who claim that the timing is inconsistent with documented history, as at the time of the alleged voyage (1398), the Order of the Knights Templar was not in existence, having been publicly disbanded ninety years earlier.

Potter, New York: {{ISBN|1-55109-122-4}} * [[Robert Ellis Cahill]], ''New England's Ancient Mysteries'', 1993, Old Saltbox, Danvers, Mass: {{ISBN|0-9626162-4-9}} * David Goudsward, ''Ancient Stone Sites of New England'', 2006, McFarland Publishing: {{ISBN|0-7864-2462-1}} * David Goudsward, ''Westford Knight and Henry Sinclair'', 2010, McFarland Publishing: {{ISBN|0-7864-4649-8}} * David S.
